title: Bracket Journaling
blurb: Moleskines for Monkey Mind

title: Practical Panpsychism
blurb: What if your fridge had a soul? Would you keep it clean?

title: Microreflection
blurb: Tweet to yourself, spreadsheet diaries, soul sampling.

title: Greenishness
blurb: Brokenhearted about breaking your streak? Let Greenishness Be Thy Motivation.

title: Allocation Mind
blurb: When "growth mindset" hits its limits, it's time for another approach.

title: G-Ray Vision
blurb: A mock superpower for not looking at porn.

title: Weekend Luddite 2025: The Rules, The Persona
blurb: Specific rules and a general approach for managing your relationship with technology -- battle hardened by over 20 years of practice.

title: The Wisdom of Games
blurb: Game mechanics as life hacks (also some game recommendations)

title: State of the Systems 2024
blurb: 6th annual review of the Everyday Systems and how they are doing for me personally

title: Zeno's Paradox Exercise Progress Plan -or- How to Philosophize with a Sledgehammer
blurb: Bounce back from injuries and setbacks by recasting progress as a reward

title: Proactive Procrastination (ProPro)
blurb: How to stop permasnacking on news. Use techniques inspired by the No S Diet and read it like a meal.

title: The Metaphysics of Todo Listing
blurb: Todo Lists Are Your Salvation / Todo Lists Are Your Damnation

title: Variable-Height Glass Ceiling
blurb: A more nuanced approach to systematically moderating alcohol (and other substances)

title: Motive Mixologist
blurb: When you don't like what you want

title: Urban Ranger 2024
blurb: Urban Ranger, from scratch, as if I’d never spoken or written about it before. Draft chapter for the upcoming Everyday Systems Compendium, and hopefully interesting and useful in its own right.

title: The Hygiene Hypothesis as the Explanation for Everything
blurb: Cure all your ailments with dirt, pain and danger

title: The No S Diet 2024
blurb: The No S Diet, from scratch, as if I’d never spoken or written about it before. Draft chapter for the upcoming Everyday Systems Compendium, and hopefully interesting and useful in its own right.

title: Clock & Calendar, your Sword & Shield
blurb: Build habits by leaning on the clock and calendar rather than fighting against them. Beyond N and S days. Cutesy task phrases. Powerfully silly times. Calendar-First Tasking.

title: State of the Systems 2023
blurb: Annual update on all the Everyday Systems and how they are doing for me personally

title: Antimantras & Repetitive Thought Injuries
blurb: I think I mix about 14 metaphors in this episode: We’ve got a goose-stepping white bear baseball player with devil horns doing jiu jitsu on the death star. A ridiculous chimera, if you put it all together. But maybe just the guardian-gargoyle image you need to keep the antimantras at bay.

title: My Pet Demon
blurb: Self-saboteur? Time to stop playing with your pet demons (maybe).

title: Spider Hunter, a CBT for Anxiety Game
blurb: Anxious? Here's a fun technique for getting over it. It's halfway between gamified mindfulness and exposure therapy.

title: Aristotelian Self-Portrait
blurb: Aristotle: "You are what you repeatedly do." Well, what do you repeatedly do? In this episode, an exercise for finding out.

title: My Friend, ChatGPT
blurb: Practice being human with AI

title: Apps for Mentats
blurb: Everyday Systems as apps for human minds

title: Tidiness for Demihumans
blurb: Four catchphrases for tidier habits.

title: Demihuman
blurb: A lighthearted approach to imposter syndrome.

title: State of the Systems 2022
blurb: A little later and much shorter than last year.

title: Last Wordism
blurb: A two-word anti-mantra to snap you and your family out of automatic bickering.

title: Surgical Flogging
blurb: Food logging: apparently it works. But it's torture to do long term. I discuss a way you can practice a limited, strategic, surgical form of food logging with the No S Diet (or any other diet) that gives you the benefits of food logging – which are real, potentially at least – without the protracted and probably futile misery.

title: Shovelglove Recovery
blurb: After 20 years of swinging my sledgehammer injury-free, I discovered that that even Shovelglove can cause or at least be impacted by injury. How Shovelglove principles like "schedulalistically insignificant time" and "maintenance is more important that progress" have been key to my recovery.

title: How to be Ordinary
blurb: Be a Mensch, not a rockstar. It's surprisingly hard, even though you probably don't have any alternative.

title: Demogorgon Whack-a-mole
blurb: What to do when your appetites keep routing around your rules to contain them

title: Right Relationship with Robots
blurb: Technology for habits, and habits for technology. Also a story about my Roomba.

title: Mindful Bagful
blurb: A lighthearted "Jedi mind trick" for calming yourself down in certain mundane situations

title: State of the Systems 2021, Part 3 (Meta Systems)
blurb: Meta systems are systems for tracking and bolstering other systems. Systems discussed include: Personal Punch Cards, The Life Log, Mantrafication, and Loose Lips Sink Ships

title: State of the Systems 2021, Part 2 (Soul Systems)
blurb: Soul systems are systems for detaching yourself from the frenzy of everyday life to reflect, for learning, for recovering, for devoting more of your limited time to what’s important, for figuring out what’s important to begin with. Systems discussed include: Audiodidact. The Study Habit. Demogorgon vs. Asmodeus, Timebox Lord, G-Ray Vision, VC Cat, Posifactive and Weekend Luddite..

title: State of the Systems 2021, Part 1 (Body & Spirits)
blurb: 2021 was miserable in most respects, but it’s been another fantastic opportunity to test the true mettle of Everyday Systems. Part 1 reviews Body and Spirits systems: The No S Diet, Shoveglove, Urban Ranger, Lawful Good Biker, Glass Ceiling, Low Smoking.

title: VC Cat
blurb: An inspiringly ridiculous image to ward off the dreaded "what the hell" effect.

title: The Study Habit, Part 2 (Behavioral)
blurb: Specific techniques for making study a daily habit.

title: The Study Habit
blurb: How to go from 'study=cramming' to making learning a lifelong habit.

title: Loose Lips Sink Ships
blurb: Image from WWII propaganda to keep you from sabotaging your own self-improvement efforts.

title: Posifactive
blurb: All the self-help books ever written distilled into one word.

title: Good Redundancy
blurb: Engineer intentional redundancy into your habit systems to make them fault tolerant.

title: The Lifelog
blurb: Habit tracking when apps or magic markers won't cut it.

title: State of the Systems 2020
blurb: How pandemic proof are the Everyday systems? A quick review of 14 systems and how they are holding up.

title: Timebox Lord
blurb: A system for balancing "infinite work" with "first things."

title: Demogorgon vs. Asmodeus
blurb: How to ingore both of the evil voices in your head and attain comic detachment from your psychomachia.

title: Mantrafication
blurb: Reflect on what is giving you trouble with your self improvement system. Write a contract with yourself on a 4*6 index card. Record yourself speaking it. Listen to this recorded mantra every day.

title: 2016 State of the Systems Check-In (Spiritual)
blurb: No S for the Soul! 14-Year Jubilee updates on 8 "spiritual" systems: Weekend Luddite, Audiodidact, Chain of Self-command, Low Smoking, G-Ray Vision, Monthly Resolution, Lawful Good Biker and The Study Habit.

title: 2016 State of the Systems Check-In (Physical)
blurb: It's been 14 years since everyday systems first went online. How are they holding up? In this episode I report on the four physical systems: the No S Diet, Shovelglove, Urban Ranger, and Glass ceiling.

title: The No S Diet Audiobook, Chapter 1 (Rough!)
blurb: Are my low podcast production values good enough to produce an audiobook? You be the judge! For this episode, an experimental reading of Chapter 1 of the No S Diet book. Let me know if a few tweaks here and there might do the trick, or if I had better rethink this whole project.

title: The Heroics of Tidiness
blurb: Habit is powerful. But is it always the answer? Is there room for one-time, decisive actions in the realm of self-improvement? I think there is -- but perhaps not quite where you expect it.

title: S-days vs. Cheat Days
blurb: S-days aren't cheat days -- in an important way, they're the opposite.

title: Einstein's Soup
blurb: An Einsteinian justification for my irregular podcasting

title: The Return of the General
blurb: Long term planning with index cards is back! You can now capture your entire life strategy, operations, and tactics in three index cards.

title: Scribal Filter and medium-term task management
blurb: No-tech medium term task managment with index cards.

title: Personal Punchcards Redux
blurb: Low-tech, high-psychology productivity tracking gets even simpler.

title: The "What the Hell" Effect and Negative Qualification.
blurb: The "what the hell" effect sounds funny but it can seriously screw you up. How can everyday systems practitioners defend against it?

title: No Solitary Snacking -- even on S days.
blurb: Hate your S-days because they make you feel out of control? Here's a mod to help you enjoy them again.

title: Lawful Good Biker
blurb: Change your biker-alignment to Lawful Good. Be flamboyantly, comically observant of traffic rules.

title: 14 minutes of ANYTHING
blurb: Looking for an exercise routine but not so into the idea swinging a sledgehammer around? Introducing shovelglove without the sledgehammer.

title: The Mods and Tweaks Trilogy Part III: When a mere mod isn't enough
blurb: How to roll your own everyday system from scratch. Introducing the idea of Systematic Moderation.

title: The Mods and Tweaks Trilogy Part II: How To Tweak
blurb: Still want to tweak an Everyday System? Here's how.

title: The Mods and Tweaks Trilogy Part I: To Tweak Or Not To Tweak
blurb: Want to modify an Everyday System? It's possible -- but risky, as this episode emphasizes. Subtitled: 'In Praise of Vanilla.'

title: S-days Gone Wild
blurb: Feel like over the top S-days are undoing all your hard work during the week? Here's how to diagnose and correct this problem.

title: 2007 Annual Compliance Review
blurb: How well do I practice what I preach? What level of compliance is necessary for big picture success? What's the hardest everyday system? I attempt to answer these questions in my first annual self performance review.

title: The Bigger (8x11) Picture
blurb: Just as your daily task list should fit on a single 3x5 index card (see Chain of Self Command and Personal Punch Cards), your life strategy should fit on an single 8x11 sheet of paper

title: What is the best piece of exercise equipment money can buy?
blurb: You may think you know the answer to this already -- or at least, the answer I am going to give you. But you're probably wrong. Because it's not a sledgehammer. Or even a sledgehammer with a sweater wrapper around it. It's a timer.

title: Introducing the HabitCal
blurb: The HabitCal is a free online tool I came up with to track and build habits. In this podcast I explain how to use it and why.

title: Top 5 health and fitness books (sort of)
blurb: I've been asked to talk about the top five health and fitness books I've read. Unfortunately I don't think I've read that many health and fitness books in my entire life, and they certainly weren't all worth recommending. So I'm going to have to narrow it down to four. And I'll be cheating a little because one of them hasn't even been published yet.

title: A 90% diet solution -- in 2 words
blurb: According to data from the Continuing Surveys of Food Intake by Individuals, conducted by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, 90% of our increased calorie consumption since 1977 has come from increased between-meal eating. Calories consumed at meals have stayed about the same. If this statistic is accurate, snacking is not only the biggest problem in terms of dietary excess, it is almost the entire problem.

title: Audiodidact (Output)
blurb: Talk to yourself -- and record it. Why? Autotherapy. Catch all those great ideas that would have gotten away otherwise. Nag yourself into doing impossible tasks. Keep an even-keel diary that reflects a broader range of experience. Give serious books the serious attention they require.

title: Audiodidact (Input)
blurb: No time to read? Hate mindless but necessary chores? Solve both problems at once by listening to audiobooks while you do housework.

title: Compound and Atomic Tasks
blurb: Consolidate well-understood routine tasks into compound tasks. Break up poorly understood novel tasks into atomic components.

title: Put the Scale in Perspective
blurb: How I lost 10 pounds, overnight, without even trying.

title: Intelligent Dietary Defaults
blurb: Convenience is stronger than you are. Accept this fact. But with a little planning, the convenient thing doesn't have to be too awful. Case in point: 'optimize your oatmeal.'

title: In Defense of 'Failure'
blurb: Stop using evasive euphemisms. Own up to 'failure' or you become it.

title: Extreme Moderation
blurb: Moderation isn't mushy. Learn from extremists by drawing hard lines -- just draw them in different places. Get the clarity of cold turkey abstinence without the sweeping deprivation.

title: When you don't have 14 minutes
blurb: No time to exercise? Get philosophical. Use enlightened self-mockery, a neo-Kantian personal categorical imperative, and an existential leap of action to get you moving.

title: Personal Punch Cards
blurb: How to use index cards for todo lists at the three scales of the chain of command: daily, monthly, yearly.

title: Chain of Self-Command
blurb: Organize your self improvement efforts on three temporal scales: year=general, month=officer, day=footsoldier.

title: Personal Olympics
blurb: Make your goals fun, important, and attainable with Personal Olympics.

title: Monthly Resolution
blurb: A month is a much better granularity than the more typical yearly resolution we make on new years, because you can estimate better on that smaller scale, and recover and reset faster. And it's long enough (over 21 days!) for some habituation to occur, even with a slip up or two.

title: Season's Warnings
blurb: Limit your celebratory eating to the holidays themselves. Adjust your expectations so that your goal is mere maintenance. If you screw up, don't wait till new years to get back on the wagon.

title: Top 5 Arbitrary Numbers
blurb: One thing that every self help guru can agree on is that you have to have an arbitrary number in your system. It is a little weird that the most rational concepts we have available to us -- numbers -- are so irrationally inspiring. But it clearly is the case.

title: Strictness
blurb: Strictness builds habit faster. Dumb down what to be strict about with fence around the law. Avoid punishment and reparations.

title: 21 days and Negative Tracking
blurb: Use the full habit traffic light for 21 days to build your habit, then switch to more efficient negative tracking.

title: Habit Tracking with the Habit Traffic Light
blurb: Need to keep track of something? Keep track of behavior, not results, with the Habit Traffic Light. Mark each calendar day with green for success, red for failure, yellow for exempt (S-days). It's cheap and keeps you focused on what you can control.

title: Habit Friendly Behaviors
blurb: How to identify behaviors that are easily automated into unconscious habit.

title: Habit Management
blurb: Want results? Frame your goals in terms of behavior. Results goals are just wishful thinking. Automate conscious behaviors into unconscious habits.

title: Glass Ceiling
blurb: Smooth out dangerous and humiliating binge drinking into moderate and pleasurable moderate drinking with a 2 drink a day glass ceiling.

title: Weekend Luddite
blurb: For every labor saving device there seem to be at least two time consuming devices to soak up all that freed time again. As T.S. Eliot put it, we are "distracted by distraction from distraction." Weekend Luddite is a system that addresses (at least in part) this problem of distraction management.

title: Urban Ranger
blurb: Reimagine yourself so that walking becomes the most important, the most exciting thing you could possibly be doing.

title: Shovelglove Time
blurb: 14 minutes is one minute less than the smallest unit of schedulistically significant time. No calendar has a finer granularity than 15 minutes. No one ever has a meeting that starts at 9:05 or 9:14. You have no excuse not to do this. Time-wise, it doesn't even register.

title: Shovelglove Sledgehammer Workout Overview
blurb: Take a sledgehammer and wrap an old sweater around it. This is your "shovelglove." Every week day morning, set a timer for 14 minutes. Use the shovelglove to perform shoveling, butter churning, wood chopping and other motions until the timer goes off. Stop. Rest on weekends and holidays.

title: No S Diet Rules
blurb: Last week I gave a high level overview of the no s diet to give you a sense of how something this simple could possibly work. This week I'm going to zoom in a little to a smaller scale and go over each of the rules in a bit of detail.

title: No S Diet Overview
blurb: A life altering diet plan in 14 words. How can something this simple possibly work?

title: Everyday Systems Overview
blurb: Five years ago, I had all the usual self improvement problems. I was fat. I smoked too much. I drank too much. I exercised too little. And I diddled away all my free time in front of the computer. Low self esteem, that problem I guess I didn't really have, beyond what can be expected of a fat, slothful, drunk who wastes all his free time. So I came up with a bunch of simple, common sense self improvement systems to fix these problems. And they worked...
